chapter.title: Presentation
chapter.para: The Text Filter plugin allows you to use text from a jEdit buffer as input to an external process, and capture the process' output into a jEdit buffer.

chapter.title: Using the Text Filter plugin
chapter.para: There are two main ways to use the plugin: running a filter once, or creating a filter that will be stored in the plugin's configuration file.

To run a filter once, choose the "Run filter" option from the plugin's menu (under jEdit's Plugins menu). To create a new filter, choose the "Create new filter" option. The "Remove filter" option allows you to delete one of the created filters.
The only limitation is that the name of the filters cannot have the "," (comma) character.
To substitute and existing filter, just create a new filter and give it the same name as an existing one. You'll be promped for whether you want to overwrite the existing filter.
Below, the several options available for the filter are explained.
These options control from where the external process expects to collect the data that Text Filter will provide.

listitem.para: Standard IN: the text will be passed to the external process via the standard input. The most common form of transfer, used by most UNIX utilities.
Argument: the text will be passed to the external process as an argument line. If the text contains more than one word, this will mean the external process will receive more than one argument.

String: the text will be passed to the external process as a string. This means that the text will be escaped and surrounded by quotes, and the external process will see all the text as a single argument.

chapter.para: When choosing something other than "standard in", be aware that if the process being called expect input though stdin, it will hang waiting for input, and jEdit will be unusable until you kill the offending process.
This option tells Text Filter where to look for the text to pass to the external process.

listitem.para: Buffer: use all the content of the buffer as input to the external process.
Selection: use the current selection as input. Will generate an error in case nothing is selected.
None: will call the external process without providing any other information that that present in the given command line. The same warning about processes that expect input from stdin applies here.

chapter.para: This option controls what will be done with the output of the process once the external program finishes its execution.

listitem.para: New Buffer: creates a new jEdit buffer and appends the output of the process to it.
Selection: substitues the current selection with the output from the process. If no selection exists, the output is appended to the current caret position.
Append: the output of the process is appended to the end of the active buffer.

chapter.para: When executing external processes, errors may occur. In case any errors are seen on stderr, a dialog is shown with the error output and you are given the option to discard any output the process has generated, or process the output anyway.
